Dom Dei: It's just a game of numbers though. Like if you **really** want to succeed with this you'd be posting 3-4 times per day. That's what mike and I were doing on our come up. Spread across 3 platforms? That's 9-12 videos being put out per day, 270 to 360 videos **per month**. Like you really think after posting 300+ videos in a month that not *one* of those is going to go viral and generate you huge sales? But it's hard when you're posting 1 video per day max
Dom Dei: and yeah, you can definitely get to making enough to cover the shopify plan hahah.

Dom Dei: you should try to go for a more aesthetic, luxurious feel. You're kind of going with a goofier sound and with this video if I didn't know you I wouldn't even really know it's about the case. Try to create an experience where you open up by reading the hate comment, then right away saying how the case is too strong, luxurious, powerful for anything to harm it. A hook I like better is something like this:

"You think dropping a **X** on the middle of your phone would damage it? Of course not, not with the **X** case. We've designed the strongest, yet sleekest designed iPhone case which....."

Then you don't even have to really drop the rock on the phone, you can just hook them in with that hate comment which gets them interested, then just talk about how good your case is and "forget" to drop the rock on your phone. So you've captured their attention, and with that you've been able to sell them on your product for 20+ seconds

root: Alex Robinson: Gotcha, so overall it's better to just refund them and not deal with shipping the product back?

MikeChamberlin: So this depends on the reason why the customer is asking for a refund. If the product broke or doesn‚Äôt function right (and it wasn‚Äôt the customers fault) you would want to just refund them through Shopify. In some cases you could have them send it back (maybe the bought the wrong size) but typically there‚Äôs no point as the cost to ship it back will be more than the actual product cost. Where it kinda get tricky is when a customer just doesn‚Äôt like the product or ‚Äúdecides they don‚Äôt want it‚Äù after it arrives‚Ä¶ Which for me, I will typically just try to explain that they bought it in the first place but refund them if they are really being pain.
replies: Alex Robinson: Gotcha, so overall it's better to just refund them and not deal with shipping the product back?

In some cases you could have them send it back (maybe the bought the wrong size) but typically there‚Äôs no point as the cost to ship it back will be more than the actual product cost. Where it kinda get tricky is when a customer just doesn‚Äôt like the product or ‚Äúdecides they don‚Äôt want it‚Äù after it arrives‚Ä¶ Which for me, I will typically just try to explain that they bought it in the first place but refund them if they are really being pain.

root: Cyris: Tik Tok algorithm after my knowdlege works this way: Your Video gets shown to 200 People and then Tik Tok analyze how these 200 people interacted with your content. If they liked it and you have long watch time it will get shown to more people. if these 200 people just skip cause the content is boring / not appealing Tik Tok wont push videos to more people cause they know no one wants to see it üòù
replies: dziobak: thx ill remember that

root: cadaur: all 1st world countries have extremely similar tax codes, but the USA has the most beneficial one for business owners.
cadaur: It's not like you have to do all this stuff instantly, just pointing it out to keep it in mind because the longer you wait, the more painful it gets lol.
cadaur: This much is for sure lol, DO NOT run a sole propietorship.
cadaur: Obviously there's caveats, so speak with an **experienced** CPA or firm.
cadaur: If you open as just a straight S-Corp, you don't have limited liability.
cadaur: Best of both worlds is starting as an LLC and transforming it into an S-Corp. You still get  the liability protection in this case and the tax benefits of the S corp.
cadaur: All this stuff will go on your form 1040, which is the same form that gets used for your job, huge red flag for auditors.
cadaur: Particularly single member.
cadaur: Just pointing that out.
cadaur: As an LLC, you cannot pay yourself a salary.
Bram101: ^True that
cadaur: Making money is great, but you **must** be vigilant about taxes. The government will always take their cut whether you try to be open about it or not.
cadaur: If you want more info, you can DM me and I can possibly give pointers
cadaur: File under an S-Corp in this situation and pay yourself a reasonable wage for your title from that company.
cadaur: USA specific ^
cadaur: You are losing abhorrent amounts of money to taxes that you do NOT need to, and it's also the **most** audited.
cadaur: DO NOT FILE YOUR TAXES UNDER AN LLC.
cadaur: To EVERYONE here who is a W2 employee and is running an ecom business
replies: cadaur: File under an S-Corp in this situation and pay yourself a reasonable wage for your title from that company.

MikeChamberlin: Setting short and long term goals is the first step and along with that simply make a to do list that is non negotiable everyday. It could be "do product research for 1 hour" or "post 2 videos of product" but make it attainable and something you basically force yourself to do everyday. It will then get built into your day to day life from there and you can keep expanding and growing it. Momemtum is key so you just gotta start building it

root: Dom Dei: that's awesome bro. one issue I had in the past was continuing to find a way to get a technically prohibited (but highly profitable) offer to run on tiktok. I ended up spiraling trying so hard to get it approved that looking back I likely couldve made more money if i focused on something that didnt have an issue. My advice to you is that it's great that you're grinding to get approval and it sounds like you will, but if the snap team continues throwing things at you and keeps making excuses as to why you can't run the medication ad it's probably best to just leave it. If this is a quick process to approval though it should be well worth it!
